Questions.Question: Pinging all IP addresses on a network is referred to as a:
Questions.Explanation: A ping sweep is when a user identifies all hosts active in a network by sending a ping to every IP address in the network.

Questions.Question: Pinging all IP addresses on a network is an efficient means of identifying active hosts in a network.
Questions.Explanation: Systems on a network may ignore the ping due to firewall settings, causing this technique to fail.

Questions.Question: Attackers can exploit applications over a network with the help of port scanning.
Questions.Explanation: By determining which ports are open, attackers can determine which services can be connected to. Services may have vulnerabilities that can then be exploited by these attackers.

Questions.Question: Faster scans have a higher chance of being detected by IDS systems due to their speed.
Questions.Explanation: A fast scan might overwhelm a system, while a slower scan is more likely to go undetected.

Questions.Question: The CPU will execute the wrong instructions if the return pointer on a stack is manipulated.
Questions.Explanation: The return pointer is a memory address dictating where the CPU should next execute instructions. If this is manipulated, attackers can effectively determine which instructions are executed.

Questions.Question: Which type of cyberattack requires the manipulation of memory stored within a stack to achieve it?
Questions.Explanation: Buffer overflows are a cyberattack involving the manipulation of memory within a stack to achieve unintended effects. For example, attackers can control the instructions the CPU executes by manipulating the return pointer on the stack.

Questions.Question: Firewalls are capable of denying incoming connections by closing ports.
Questions.Explanation: Firewalls are able to deny incoming connections by closing off ports that should not be open. As ports can only be accessed if they are not in use, only unused open ports can be used to make a connection.

Questions.Question: GUIDs and UUIDs are both examples of magic numbers, they are unsuitable to be used as resource identifiers.
Questions.Explanation: Magic numbers are typically numbers that are simple sequences of numbers, they are unsuitable for use as an identifier for a document. Both GUIDs (globally unique identifiers) and UUIDs (universally unique identifiers) are designed to be difficult to enumerate through.

Questions.Question: Parameterised queries are:
Questions.Explanation: Parameterised queries are a solution to countering SQL injections by sanitising user input to meet certain conditions.

Answers.Text: A solution to countering SQL injections.
One way of sanitising user input.
A type of query in which the inputs are checked to ensure they meet a certain data type or value.

Questions.Question: XSS attacks do not target the server, but instead use it to attack visitors instead.
Questions.Explanation: XSS (cross-site scripting) attacks manipulate a server to attack its own visitors by reflecting the attackers data onto any visitors.

Questions.Question: A stored XSS attack can be characterised by which of the following:
Questions.Explanation: Stored XSS attacks occur when an attacker stores malicious content on a webpage. This content is reflected onto visitors when they load the page. This attack does not always require for a link to be entered though, as the stored data can appear indirectly in many different places.

Answers.Text: Always require a link to be clicked.
Involves storing malicious content on a webpage.
The attacker's data is reflected onto visitors of an affected webpage.
Involves storing malicious content on a webpage, where the attacker's data is reflected onto visitors of the webpage.

Questions.Question: Using CSP headers and encoding user output correctly are both valid techniques to prevent XSS attacks.
Questions.Explanation: CSP headers can be used to dictate how JavaScript code is run, and where it can be run from. Encoding user output is also useful as it can control how the user output is viewed by visitors.

Questions.Question: Which of the following is not true about CSP?
Questions.Explanation: CSP (Content security policy) can defend against vulnerabilities, but cannot entirely eliminate all of them. There is always the potential for unknown vulnerabilities to exist.

Answers.Text: It removes all potential vulnerabilities revolving around JavaScript.
A common CSP is too provide users with all of the valid JavaScript sources files to be used.
Users may be able to report CSP violations to the server.
A CSP can prevent the execution of in-line JavaScript.

Questions.Question: Which of the following is not a web-based cyberattack?
Questions.Explanation: Buffer overflow attacks are not web-based attacks as they primarily occur elsewhere.

Questions.Question: WIFI signals tend to reach everyone within the range of the signal. This can be problematic as attackers can listen for packets traveling in the network.
Questions.Explanation: Attackers can sniff the network to listen for any traffic being transmitted throughout the network.

Questions.Question: WIFI can potentially allow attackers to:
Questions.Explanation: Attackers can access a user's internal applications, exploit firmware vulnerabilities that are unpatched and even sniff packets across a network.

Answers.Text: Exploit vulnerabilities in the firmware of WIFI devices.

Questions.Question: Some network cards allow for packets to be created with a source MAC address that is different from its own MAC address.
Questions.Explanation: Many WIFI attacks rely on the ability to create packets with a different source MAC address to achieve their effects.

Questions.Question: Which of the following is not a valid protocol used for PSK?
Questions.Explanation: WPA and WEP are both valid protocols used for authentication via PSK.

Questions.Question: Attackers can infiltrate a WPA enabled network by using a password cracker.
Questions.Explanation: WPA can still be cracked by using a password cracker. Despite this, networks with strong passwords will still be considerably difficult to crack.

Questions.Question: Clients may automatically connect to fake WIFI networks if they use the same SSID as a known network.
Questions.Explanation: Some devices may automatically connect to the fake networks if the SSID is the same. This opens the potential for attackers to sniff traffic or manipulate a user's traffic.

Questions.Question: Full-knowledge penetration testing is more valuable than no-knowledge testing.
Questions.Explanation: Teams with more knowledge of a system can exploit it with much more ease, making the penetration testing more useful in determining vulnerabilities.

Questions.Question: How might a stolen laptop be exploited by an attacker?
Questions.Explanation: Exploiting the hard-drive, exploiting applications that are left open and using a malicious network card are all valid ways in which a stolen laptop can be exploited.

Answers.Text: By utilising the hard-drive in the laptop to extract data from it.
By exploiting any applications that are running in the background.
By adding a malicious network card to the system.

Questions.Question: Social engineering involves fooling users into accidentally exposing data, among other things.
Questions.Explanation: Attackers can use social engineering to fool users into completing actions that can help achieve the attacker's goals.

Questions.Question: Vishing and phishing attacks are both entirely preventable with improved education in organisations.
Questions.Explanation: There is always the potential for attackers to gain access to systems via phishing, even if the users of the system are educated on phishing. Better security systems and authentication should also be used to improve phishing prevention.

Questions.Question: Penetration testing is a method used by attackers to infiltrate a system, it is detrimental to the security of systems.
Questions.Explanation: Penetration testing is used as a way to identify vulnerabilities before attackers can, to improve the security of a system.

Questions.Question: Which of the following are valid areas in which penetration testing can occur?
Questions.Explanation: Social engineering, networks and phishing are all valid areas in which penetration testing can be used.

Questions.Question: Passphrases are ineffective passwords as they are easily guessed.
Questions.Explanation: Passphrases are effective as passwords as they are easier to type and remember, but also harder to crack than shorter passwords.

Questions.Question: Which of the following is not true about password managers?
Questions.Explanation: Password managers are typically used to store all of a user's passwords in one location. Their main purpose is not to automatically change the passwords that a user uses.

Answers.Text: They can sometimes generate passwords for users.
They are mainly used to automatically change a user's passwords.
They are mainly used to store all of a user's passwords.

Questions.Question: Which of the following are not methods usable in multi-factor authentication?
Questions.Explanation: SMS services, QR codes and biometric authentication are all valid ways to enforce multi-factor authentication.

Questions.Question: An administrator account can be more easily compromised if:
Questions.Explanation: An administrator account can more easily be compromised under many circumstances. Some examples include having no multi-factor authentication, using the default password or writing down passwords publicly.

Answers.Text: An employee who knows the password writes it down publicly.
The account's password has never changed from the default.

Questions.Question: Credential stuffing is an attack in which leaked credentials are used against other services to access accounts.
Questions.Explanation: Credential stuffing can be used to hack into accounts, especially when users reuse passwords in multiple locations.

Questions.Question: A system's credentials cannot be extracted, even if a user is currently logged into the system when it is compromised.
Questions.Explanation: An attacker can potentially extract the credentials used for a system if administrator access is granted to it while it is compromised.
